job_title: Community Health Specialist in Granite City, IL
pros: After COVID and the ensuing lockdown, Chestnut Health Systems adapted by making many positions eligible for working remotely. I find this arrangement to be very desirable, as it allows me to focus more fully on doing my work rather than preparing for it. I set my own workday, which I love!
cons: No downside, other than my being "out of the office" may have reinforced a sense of disconnect with colleagues. The sheer size of Chestnut feels grander and more remote than it might otherwise be.

review_title: Very small cog in very large wheel.
pros: I felt like there was opportunity to make a big difference in people's lives. Overall, good training, but starting salaries not enough to keep good people so they're sending out well-trained people to other agencies. Decent benefits and a reasonable chance of promotion.
cons: 1. Huge organization with layers and layers of supervisors. You may have a supervisor that has no duty other than settling an argument between you and a co-worker and writing your yearly eval (which has to be signed off by his or her supervisor anyway). It's a big tangle of bureaucracy (or a child's game of telephone)! No problem or issue is solved easily. 2. I felt like the consumers were not the focus of this agency, even though that is (of course) the stated goal. And I understand that places have to make money to stay in business. But the constant focus on productivity as the bottom line is depressing and demoralizing.

pros: Healthcare Benefits. Work schedule. Client interaction.

job_title: Crisis Intervention Specialist in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
I get to make my own schedule as a PRN staff. 
I got a raise so far due to them increasing the salaries which is very good.
I have a good supportive supervisor. 
I also got a nice size retention bonus.
The work is rewarding, frustrating at times, but if you enjoy helping people you will be fine.
cons: The only issue I have is as a Crisis Intervention Specialist you have to use your own car. Now I live in St. Louis so I'm often doing quit a bit of traveling therefore I wished they reimbursed for mileage coming from your home, instead of one of their Illinois offices.

pros: The only reason to work here is if you’re in desperate need of a job.
cons:
It’s a miracle that the entire community doesn’t stand up and shame this place—which is probably only the case because the people who work here are so passionate about helping the people this company says it serves. 

The recovery program is so backwards it isn’t even funny. The curriculum is old and goofy and you don’t even need any particular training to teach it. The supervisor of the unit almost never came down to the unit, but did spend most of her time watching the cameras. Any time she didn’t like what she saw, she would call the unit to yell at you. Pretty unhinged. Everyone on this unit lost their job when chestnut announced, with a two week notice, that they were closing the unit and moving it downstate.

The pay is LAUGHABLE at best. I was paid around 11 an hour with a B.S. and the hardest working woman on the unit at the time had been working there for a few years and only made 25,000 a year. Salary discussion was, of course, discouraged (illegal). I’ve seen people with masters in psychology be offered 30,000 to work here. Full time employees on the unit usually had second jobs AT Chestnut just to make ends meet. It’s sick. 

This company doesn’t give a single crap about the people that work their butts off to serve the hardest hit folks in our community. We should run them out of town.

pros:
Challenged daily to continue to grow
Winning Culture 
Opportunities for growth in unique ways
Impact others in a positive way
Good benefits
cons:
Rigid work schedules
Start as a contractor

pros: Working full time includes benefits of personal time (given yearly), vacation time (given yearly/based upon seniority), and sick time (roughly 6 hours for every month completed).  Depending upon the area you work, you will get the opportunity to work with a supportive team who cares and wishes to get to know you personally outside of the daily routine. For someone with just a bachelors degree there is opportunity for full time experience which can open many doors to certification and expansion of professional skills. For those with a master's degree there are options to getting supervision in order to get licensure, but be prepared to actively reach out to find a licensed supervisor.
cons: Challenges of this position include being on the go constantly from start to finish. If working residential, you will likely be working to balance not only client supervision, but also coordinating groups, individual sessions, and family sessions.  Caseload may seem small roughly 2-3 clients, but established commitments and expectations can be overwhelming and lead to burnout if self care is not taken into consideration. Also, the pay compared to established expectations and experience is not rewarded.  This position is a great opportunity for those with little experience, but for someone who has been in the residential field and very knowledgeable to substance abuse this will likely provide little opportunity for further professional growth/development.

pros: When I finished my undergraduate work, I was hoping to get an opportunity to help adolescents with drug and alcohol problems. Chestnut provided me that chance.  What I loved about working there was that the supervisors are patient with you and are willing to help you every step of the way. Day or night I knew I could consult with my supervisor and not feel like I was a bother to him or her. If you really want to make a difference in a kid's life or a parent's life...this is the perfect job right out of college. They'll help you get certified in the field and explore more opportunities at Chestnut along the way.
cons: Cons to some are the busy residential routine. There's always something to do for the clients or your co-workers. You'll start out workingbevenings, but with good work habits, you'll move up to better hours eventually. Salary is competitive with other jobs right out of school. There's promotions if you gain advanced degrees and/or experience.

pros: Chestnut provides a good working atmosphere. Staff is pretty laid back and they do what they can to keep employee morale up. The company is always working to improve practices and efficiency working with what they are given as a non-profit agency. They really try to work with your schedule and meet your personal and professional needs. Supervisors and management work hard to help you set and meet your goals to further your experience. Overall, a happy, healthy work environment.
cons: As a non-profit, pay is generally low. Layoffs are also a concern on a yearly basis due relying on government funding and various grants.  Reorganization changes by upper management sometimes seem to only address short term rather than long term needs of the company. Communication can sometimes be biased to certain individuals and teams, which can be frustrating.
